moves.3... h6: There was no threat of me bringing the DSB out ...
moves.5. h3: trying to get rid of his bishop, here i have not seen it yet...
moves.7. Nxe5:
looks stupid......, this is a deceiving position due to the power of the 3 minor pieces.

If dxe5, then Qxh5 threatens mate on F7 and attacks e5, leaving me with a pawn up if he plays Qd7, white being much better in development, 3 pieces to one you should be able to convert...

If I had played this on move 5 there would be no threat for mate, it would play out as Qxg4
moves.7... Bxd1 8. Bxf7+: dont think he saw it comming, forced
moves.8... Ke7 9. Nd5#:
mate.  I was very pleased that I remembered the move, even though it was 2 moves late.

But the moral is if your oponent keeps his knights in, let it rip........

Please give some comment on any other variations you can spot?
